answer.body:
The designs of the invitation cards and publicity posters are protected by copyright as an artistic work.  Your use of such artwork depends on what was agreed between your company and the graphics designer on the use of the artwork and/or ownership of copyright in the artwork.

If there was no agreement on this issue, the default position is that the graphics designer, although commissioned by you, (or his company, if he is an employee) owns the copyright to the artwork. You should only "recycle" the designs with permission as this involves making copies of the artwork. Even though the event details will be changed, a substantial part of the artwork would have been copied and this is enough to infringe copyright.

In general, it is best to ensure at the outset that the terms of the engagement suit your company's needs. This must be agreed between both parties in writing.

questionListItems.title: Can I request for a refund for a fee for an application or form?

answer.body:
Refund may be allowed under the following list of circumstances:

- You made duplicate payment for a form.
- You filed duplicate forms.
- You submitted a form which cannot be processed.

A refund request can be submitted via IPOS Digital Hub. Forms which have been processed are generally not refundable.

Submission of a request for refund does not guarantee a refund and is subject to approval. You are advised to check your forms carefully before submitting them.

questionListItems.title: Can I request that the publication of the international registration be deferred?

answer.body: Under the Geneva (1999) Act, publication may be deferred up to 30 months. However, Singapore law does not provide for deferment of publication. Hence, if an international registration designates Singapore and the applicant wishes to proceed with the deferment, Singapore may have to be withdrawn from the list of designated countries.

questionListItems.title: Can I screen share a movie over online telecommunication platforms?

answer.body: Subscribing to a paid video on demand subscription service does not mean you have the unconditional right to stream the movie for others to watch. You should read the terms and conditions of your subscription service to ensure that your use falls within the permitted scope. You may come across terms such as ?for personal and non-commercial use? and ?may not be shared with individuals beyond your household?.

questionListItems.title: Can I still commercialise or use my invention without a patent?

answer.body:
Yes, you can commercialise or use your invention without patent protection. However, once your invention is made known to the public, you may not be able to obtain a patent if you decide to apply for protection later. 

It should also be borne in mind that apart from a patent, for certain industries, there may be legislative requirements governing the use of an invention. For example, if your invention relates to a pharmaceutical product, prior permission must be obtained from the relevant health authorities.

questionListItems.title: Can I still file voluntary amendment to the specification after Search and Examination/ Examination/ Supplementary Examination.

answer.body:
Voluntary amendments can be filed any time before payment of the fee for the grant of the patent, except -

a) after a request for a search report (Patents Form 10) has been filed and before the receipt of that report by the applicant;

b) after a request for a search and examination report (Patents Form 11), examination report (Patents Form 12) or supplementary examination report (Patents Form 12A) has been filed, unless the amendment is contained in a response to written opinion (Patents Form 13A); and

c) after a request for examination review (Patents Form 12B) is filed.

An application for an amendment to the specification is to be made on Patents Form 13. The form can be viewed  here.

Note: Request for Supplementary Examination Report is applicable for application filed before 1 January 2020 only.

questionListItems.title: Can I surrender my design after registration?

answer.body: You may apply to surrender a registered design by filing Form CM3 at no costs.

questionListItems.title: Can I transfer my patent or patent application to someone else or license it out?

answer.body:
Yes. As with other forms of IP, a patent or patent application is a right that can be assigned or licensed to another party.

An application to register such transactions with IPOS shall be made via Form CM6 (Application to register, amend or terminate licence), or Form CM8 (Application to an assignment of a registered design or any right in it) together with the prescribed fees.

questionListItems.title: Can I transfer my registered design to someone else or license it out?

answer.body:
Yes. As with other forms of IP, a registered design is a right that can be assigned or licensed to another party.
An application to register such transactions with the Registry shall be made via Form CM6 (Application to register, amend or terminate licence), or Form CM8 (Application to an assignment of a registered design or any right in it) together with the prescribed fees.

questionListItems.title: Can I use a published feature for my company's publicity?

answer.body:
Newspaper articles are protected by copyright. Whether you need the consent of the copyright owner depends on what you mean by "use" of the article. 

If, in your publicity, you merely refer to the fact that the newspaper featured your company, you do not need the newspaper's permission to do so.  

If you wish to link to an online version of the feature, you should check the website's terms and conditions on use and linking before doing so.

If you intend to reproduce the newspaper feature in your publicity material, you will need the copyright owner's consent to do so.

The copyright owner may be the newspaper itself, or the feature writer, especially if he/she is a freelancer. You should start by checking with the newspaper.

questionListItems.title: Can I copy/record training materials I obtained or accessed through a course I attended?

answer.body: Training materials, such as notes, scripts, or videos, are usually original works and therefore protected by copyright. You should always obtain permission before using (e.g., copying or recording) another person’s copyright-protected works, unless a legal exception applies. You can obtain this permission directly from the copyright owner, who may be the trainer who created the materials, or the company employing the trainer.

questionListItems.title: Can I use copyright-protected content in my own work?

answer.body:
Generally, you need to obtain permission or a licence to use a copyright-protected work before using it.

The owner of a copyright work has the exclusive right to prohibit others from using that work, so all other persons may use that work only if:

  • they obtain permission to use the work – whether directly from the copyright owner or through the relevant collective management organisation managing the relevant rights in that work;

  • an exception under the Copyright Act 2021 applies (e.g., the “fair use” exception under sections 190 – 194); or

  • the work is in the public domain – this happens when the copyright in the work has expired (e.g., copyright in musical works expire 70 years after the death of the author).


You may refer to the Copyright Infopack for more details on the above.

questionListItems.title: Can I use copyright works for text and data mining and machine learning?

answer.body:
It is a permitted use of copyright works to copy these works specifically for the purpose of computational data analysis, e.g. sentiment analysis, text and data mining, and training machine learning.  

However, there are several conditions which you must comply with:
- You cannot share copies of the works with others, except for verifying the results of the computational data analysis or for collaborative research or study relating to the purpose of such analysis;
- You must not use copies of the works made for any other purpose; - You must have lawful access to the works to be copied; and
- The work from which copies are made must not itself be an infringing copy (unless the use of infringing copies is necessary for a prescribed analysis) or you did not know that the work is an infringing copy.

questionListItems.title: Can I use images provided by portals such as Google Images and upload them on my website/blog?

answer.body:
You may do so if permitted by the terms and conditions of use of these portals. Please also check for any limitations or conditions of such use, for example only non-commercial use is permitted, or you are required to credit the photographer.

If the terms and conditions do not address your intended use of the images, you may contact the copyright owners directly for consent.

Using the images without the copyright owner’s consent is an infringement of copyright unless your use falls within the “fair use" exception under sections 190 – 194 of the Copyright Act . “Fair use” includes situations of news reporting and criticisms or review. For such uses, you will need to make a sufficient acknowledgement of the work used.

questionListItems.title: Can I use one application form for multiple classes of goods and services?

answer.body:
You may submit one application form covering more than one class of goods and/or services.

The application form should clearly state the class numbers and the corresponding goods and/or services applied for.

The cost of filing will be the filing fees for an application multiplied by the number of classes filed. For example, the cost of filing an online application covering a total of five classes whose specification items are fully adopted from the pre-approved database is S$280 X 5 = S$1,400.

agency.name: Intellectual Property Office of Singapore
agency.searchHint: cost to apply for a patent
